A Good General Servant
Apply to Mrs Outhwaite at the Drug Store.

Notices.

Public Notice.

SINTALUTTA SCHOOL.
All parties are hereby notified that the school board has appointed me teacher of the Sintalluta School district within the fol-
lowing boundaries viz: That part of Sintalut-
ta River extending from Mrs M. H. Simp-
son's Creek north west to Mrs H. Simpson's
Creek and south east to yoke 51 97 383.
Commencing at the confluence of Mississipi
River and the above mentioned creek, proceed
down said Mississipi River 30 rods southerly
and thence westerly along a straight line to
the South West corner of Section No. 15 Range
2 East Township 6 North.
Wm. Outhwaite.
(Signed) Secretary.

Notice.

NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN that an
application was made at the last meeting
of the North West Central Rail-
road Company, held in the Chamber of the
Parliament of Canada, for the formation
of a new Company from the existing North
West Central Railway Company, an
incorporated Company limited by shares
from Redvers to Belfieeld, and other
points in quoted materials for the con-
struction and operation of five miles of
railway for such purpose and rate per
mile as may be deemed necessary, and
for such period as may be deemed neces-
sary thereafter.
Toronto, 23rd Nov., 1885.
James McBeith.
President of the N.W.C.R.C.

AVIS.

AVIS subserving the notice that all
persons who may be interested in the
North West Central Railway in Canada, are
freely invited to meet in Council at the
North West Central Railway Offices at
Toronto, on Friday next, tenth November
next, at nine o'clock A.M.
The North West Central Railway Company,
are now substituted, and will continue to
make payments due at the same Office at
Toronto, 23rd Nov., 1885.
James McBeith.
President of the N.W.C.R.C.

Notice.

NOTICE TO CONTRACTORS.

SEALD TENDERS addressed to the undersigned, certified and sealed by two
responsible witnesses as approved by the
Western Section, to be received at the office
of the Western Section, Monday, the 26th No-
vember instant, at four o'clock P.M., for the
erection of a building to contain five rooms
on the first floor and the basement, together
with the erection of a saw mill, at a point
south west of Fort Qu'Appelle, about six
miles due east from Regina, for use of the
Northern Pacific Railway Company.
B. J. Bradley.
(Q.S. Department, Secretary.)

PREPARING.

We learn from authentic sources
that the Government is taking every
necessary measure to ensure the safety, life and property of the
settlers against any probable In-
dians uprising. It is reasonably to be
inferred from announcements that are now quietly going forward that
it is the intention of the Govern-
ment to disarm the Indians, and put them under such surveillances
as will prevent their being able to
reduce us to quietness. Certainly
nothing greater ever has been done to
forestall the inevitable than what is
being done by the authorities at
present. It is sufficient to know that the members of the Gov-
ernment are doing all they can to
secure the safety of the settlers. The
Department does not bind itself to
attribute this act to any particular
cause, but does urge everyone to do
its part in preserving peace and
order.

Correspondence.

To the Editor.

Sir -- As many who were not at
School last meeting on Tuesday last,
were unable to procure the news-
paper, we are induced to inform
you that although the society
have made proper arrangements
to purchase a new member, said
person may be prevented.
W. Davidson.
(Signed) Secretary.

WHY NOT ORGANIZE A VOL-
UNTEER FORCE.

For some time past alarming rumours have been from time to time
published in the columns of our
contemporaries regarding the mili-
tant and excited outbreaks which are
going on among the Indians in the west, and these
rumours have been inevitably accompa-
nied by a demand for a military force
to meet them. These rumours appear, however, to exist only in the pages of some
newspaper or other, there being nothing whatever to justify them. The only possible
answer to this question would be if
we had any military force or volunteer organization at hand ready for immediate use.
In view of this unhappy state of affairs,
I would suggest that a company of
this kind should be formed among the
citizens of Fort Qu'Appelle, who, I am sure,
would be willing to respond to such a call.
Very respectfully,
J. H. Young.
Fort Qu'Appelle, Oct. 31st.

THE INCONSISTENT LEADER.

In a whole column and a half the Leader has again raised some important issues to members of the North-West Council. We extract the following from the article referred to:

"Their (the government's) unsubstantiated confidence in the Indian Commissioner over-awed in the Department of Indian affairs and then voted for a measure containing provisions that may be construed and mis-construed to weigh the meaning of a certain sentence offending the honor of every man loyal to His Majesty in any of his capacities. They expressed readiness to vote for any measure adverse to the Dominion government on a specified subject. This course they withdrew and admitted that the measure in which it was left in doubt whether they intended to pass or blame the government. They two by two by a club rule motion they unconditionally declared their confidence in the government. A few days before, by a slender minority and an ill founded clause they had said to come."

This is quite different from the position taken by the Leader a few weeks ago. When the Council passed the motion approving of the action of the Government in carrying out the sentence against Rich, that paper and the Conservative claimed the Government was all blame in connection with the late rebellion. In this connection the opinion of one of the members of the committee was valued. That was held by the other day Mr. W. D. Perley, M. N. W. C., was asked whether it was his intention in moving the Resolution that the Committee should consider the administration of the government all blame in connection with the late rebellion, as stated by the Leader. He replied as follows:

"At the opening of the late session of the North-West Council, the Lieutenant-Governor made an elaborate speech, in which all questions affecting the territories were dealt with, and it was the duty of the Council to make a reply to it. He was appointed on the spot to make such an address as he thought best. When the council met, Mr. Seaton, Mr. Hughes, and himself were nominated as sub-committee to consider the address. They first objected saying it was hardly fair that three new members should be required to perform what was a duty. But upon being pressed, he consented as he was determined to do something. He then asked for a representative of the people to be appointed to the committee. The Lieutenant-Governor spoke very carefully and finally closed the debate and concluded to prepare a reply that it was very soon referred to him. The Dominion government, however, ignored the members of the Council on the question affecting the habitants and Indians of the West. The Government has been so tardily dealing with these questions that they felt it necessary to give them a new life. They felt it necessary to tell the Government that they should not have been delayed in doing this and that the question, and that they should not have kept the people in an uncertain state during this critical period. The Government has been slow in dealing with the question, and that they should not have kept the people in an uncertain state during this critical period. The Government has been slow in dealing with the question, and that they should not have kept the people in an uncertain state during this critical period.

SIR JOHN MACDONALD IN NEWFOUNDLAND.

The London, Edinburgh, Standard says—The Transcanada Company paid a deserved tribute of respect to Sir J. Macdonald yesterday, in presence of the Governor-General. Mr. Perley went on to show that the leader of the party not only rejected the motion but also refused to consider the question of the habitants and Indians of the West. The Government has been so tardily dealing with these questions that they felt it necessary to give them a new life. They felt it necessary to tell the Government that they should not have been delayed in doing this and that the question, and that they should not have kept the people in an uncertain state during this critical period.

NOTES AND COMMENTS.

Across the line they are having big times with snow blocks across the mainways, traffic being suspended for days together. On the C. P. R., in the Northwest a snow blockade is almost unknown. The report that was circulated that the Dominion Parliament would be dissolved and a general election take place was not met by the Government. The completion of the Canadian Pacific Railway will place the region when the weather is favorable, in a state of great prosperity. The Conservative party has been given representation in the Council and Senate. It is now seen, however, that the government has introduced a good effect upon the country. It is now seen that the government has introduced a good effect upon the country. It is now seen that the government has introduced a good effect upon the country. It is now seen that the government has introduced a good effect upon the country.

Sir John Macdonald is the practical leader of the Liberal party. He is the practical leader of the Liberal party. He is the practical leader of the Liberal party. He is the practical leader of the Liberal party.
OUR TERMS.

We have placed our yearly subscription at the low rate of ONE DOLLAR, with the object of enforcing advance payment. We can submit no other offer to publish a paper at that price; when we know that every paper going out is paid for, then if we took the chances of collecting accounts at a higher figure. Besides we will thus specially reserve a larger portion of what will enhance the value of our advertising columns. So dear reader send us your name and a dollar, and get your neighbor to subscribe, and you will obtain full value for your money in interesting reading from now till January 1st, 1857.

Rapid City Ripples.

The officers of Corinthian Lodge No. 15, A.F.A.M., have installed at the following W. M.: W. E. Cowan; S. W.: John Howard; J. W.: Mr. Webb; Chaplain: Mr. C. H. L. Isaac; Secretary: Mr. Joseph J. V. Douglas; S. D., S. L. Head; Tyler, Guy Williams, Mr. Mim- mack has been an honorary mem- ber of the lodge and Master of Ceremonies.

An Improved Tree.

In the vicinity of most Western towns and villages are clustered two trees, one green and the other brownish. They are so similar in appearance that they are often mistaken for each other. The tree whose leaf is nearly white (lycopsis) is a native of Europe, while the other is a native of Asia. When they are discarded in any way, these trees are so similar that they can be used in this country without confusion. The tree that is known as the poplar shade is a native of Asia, and has been introduced into our country by the Dutch. It is a slow growing tree, and is often planted as a shade tree. It is said to be very hardy, and will grow in almost any soil.

HOME & GOSSIP.

QU'APPELLE.
—Council meets Monday.
—Qu'Appelle party tonight.
—Wheat is up to 70 cents for No. 1 hard red.
—Our curriers are rapidly becoming proficient.
—Miss Milne has organized a musical class in town.
—Major Phipps of Summerbury was here yesterday.
—Mr. T. Fair is digging another well on Carvell Street.
—Mr. G. L. Dodds, of Wolsley called at The Progress office yesterday.
—The pay car passed here this week and cashed up to the C. P. R., boys.
—Rev. Theo. Lawson went down to Wolsley this week on missionary business.
—The Island house have been putting up rooms and other improvements this week.
—Mr. G. B. Crowe, of Winnipeg is in town. He is the guest of Thomas Thomson & Sons.
—The financial statement of the Qu'Appelle Council will appear in the next issue of The Progress.
—The net proceeds of the Presbyterian church tea and entertainment on the 25th inst. was $74.
—Mr. J. L. Burdett, who was here some time ago, has returned to town by yesterday morning's train.
—Rev. Mr. Woodsworth, President of the Manitoba Methodist Conference, expects to be in town next week.
—The blizzard on Wednesday prevented a number from attending the band at Mr. W. V. Jackson, M. N. W. C.
—Arch. Macdonald, factor of the H. R. Co., from Qu'Appelle, passed through town and went to Regina yesterday morning.
—A number of the Bell Farm people are here on Tuesday with four for the fallin reserve near north-west of here.
—Mr. Owen Owen, of the St. John's College, still in residence for the Town and Union Hall, where he is going as school teacher to the Indians.
—Quite a number of our citizens are taking advantage of the skating ring being open in the afternoon. There was a large number of ladies on skateboards yesterday.
—Judge Richardson, D. Scott, F. K. Gibson, Justice Watson, J. H. Benson, of Regina, and C. F. Clutch, of Edmonton, were present at the Island House yesterday.
—Mr. John Cook and E. C. Wilson of the Pleasant Fort Company, Metlakatla, U.S.A., are here in Qu'Appelle likely to be sworn in as P.R. by Judge Richardson.
—Mrs. Gray Jones, with her two children, went away for Christmas leave on the 9th inst. The body of the late Mrs. Gray Jones was shipped to Glasgow at the same time.
—Chas. Marshallay, M. N. W. C., Dr. James, Dr. Clark, Mr. Clarke, F. Struthers, T. C. Johnson, John Scoedt, Regina; Major Pappo, Summerberry; S. Conner, Fassler, M.N.W.C.; R. J. W. C., L. M. Jones, Winnipeg; were registered yesterday at the Queen's Hotel.

—An election will take place on Wednesday next, the 26th inst., to elect a new school trustee to succeed Mr. Danielson whose term expires. Mr. A. N. Wismer is talked of as the coming man.

—A successful banquet was given last night at the Queen's hotel to the legal fraternity and officers attending the convention. The weather was excellent while we were going to press we are compelled to hold over our report till next week.

—The annual carnival advertised to take place on Saturday evening last, was postponed on account of the snow but will be held Saturday evening. It promises to be very successful, as many are prepared to appear. Mounds has been having a successful run, and an enjoyable evening may be anticipated. The season tickets offered at ten cents each, in addition to the prices already offered there will be a half mile race open at all 21 o'clock (P.M.), price 50¢.

WOLESLEY.
(If the postman who sent the following items will send us his name, we will send him free. We do not charge for the publication of local items.)
—Cold weather for the Wolesley market—many starting latest crops.
—We had a policeman from Regina to visit us this week, and he has stopped the boys from painting the town.
—Mr. W. E. Grant is home from British Columbia on a visit to his friends. He intends to return back soon and wants to settle down. The Wolesley boys will miss him.
—There was an entertainment at the church on Wednesday last, which was quite a grand affair, but think if the Wolesley boys could pay more attention to their studies and less to the young ladies of Wolesley, they would do better.

ELLISBORO.
—At the regular meeting of the Ellisboro Church discussed the following proposition: "Resolved that it would be better to have a municipal hall built than a parochial school." Mr. J. Black occupied the chair, the leaders were L. Thompson for the affirmative and J. A. Smith for the negatives.
The chairman, after some talk up the question, declared in favor of the affirmative.
It was then moved by Mr. Thomp- son and seconded by J. A. Suther- land, that all present should be allowed to speak on whichever side of the question they chose, and that such a vote would assist the council in ascertaining what the sentiment of the parish is.
Speeches were made by Messrs. Nininger, Thompson, Dunn and others who advocated a municipal hall which resulted unanimously in favor of the municipality running the hall.

EDGELEE.
—A grand social and entertain- ment will be given at the Methodist church at Edgelle on Friday, the 22nd inst. The program will consist of choice music, restaurants, etc. Refreshments will be served during the evening. Admission 25¢.
The Edgelle Progress people are anxious about a good turn out, and we are satisfied that this one will prove worthy of the talent and ability they have in that vicinity.
We have received the following letter:
Edgelle, June 23rd.
Stockport, Ont. 27th, 1885.
Sir—I read with much interest THE QU'APPELLE PROGRESS, and I am pleased to see that Edgelle is written "Edgly" in some of the numbers. It was interesting to note that when I was there last writing and in which it was born, Ler, or as it is more familiarly written today, L. Edgely, which adjoins the town of Edgelle, is the largest producer of beef cattle in the district. If I remember right, Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Smith, who own a large spread near Edgely, raise the best beef cattle in the district. Mr. Smith is a member of the Edgely stockmen's association and is well known in the district. He is a director of the Edgely stockmen's association. Mr. Smith is also a director of the Edgely stockmen's association and is well known in the district.

EUGENE.
—Mr. Gray Jones, with his two children, went away for Christmas leave on the 9th inst. The body of the late Mrs. Gray Jones was shipped to Glasgow at the same time.

FANCY GOODS.
—Mrs. Stone & Murdock

INDIAN HEAD.
—Mr. J. A. Kanapender is getting ready for a trip, so was not able to attend the proceedings in the Progress.

INDIAN HEAD.
—Indian Head Council meets Monday next. All members have been summoned.

JACKSON.
—There will be a theatrical enter- tainment on Sunday, the 16th inst., at 2 o'clock p.m., at the church yard of St. Paul's Church. Any person going from here may be sure of spending an enjoyable evening.

KAPWA.
—Lance Corporal, of A Battery, called in today to see his friends in town. He is going to Regina to secure a horse to join his Battery stationed at Bathurst. He belongs to the cavalry of another regiment. He was most cordially welcomed by the young ladies here, who expressed themselves as being very glad to see him. We wish him a jolly trip.

THE ALTAR.
—In the Methodist Church, Metlakatla, on the 3rd inst., Rev. Theo. Lawson, M. N. W. C., Geo. Cohen, Rev., and Rev. Mr. Smith, Metlakatla, S. W. T. C., conducted services.
